Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Grant: Development of a Undergraduate Bioinformatics Program for Enhancing Research and Education at Tennessee State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tennessee State University's (TSU) Targeted Infusion Project entitled - Development of an Undergraduate Bioinformatics Program for Enhancing Research and Education at Tennessee State - has the goal to develop an undergraduate Bioinformatics program at the university. This project will initiate interdisciplinary research in the areas of bioinformatics, database design and data mining, development of data structures and algorithms for bio-information processing, and development of novel high-performance computation techniques for analyzing the structures and functions coded in molecular sequences. TSU has demonstrated growing research strength in genomics. The project will provide resources for further development of genome research.

This project will be an integral part in preparing a workforce of minority students who can compete with their peers in industry or academia in various areas of bioinformatics. The activities will enhance integration of research and education in disciplines such as biology, mathematics, and computer science. The addition of a Bioinformatics Laboratory will equip TSU with facilities that can host outreach opportunities. These activities are expected to increase interest in science and engineering, therefore increasing the recruitment and retention rates at TSU.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
OBJECTIVE-1: Establish of a Bioinformatics Laboratory that will provide a learning environment for the TSU students, and a research environment for the TSU faculty, and graduate and undergraduate students.

Outcome-1.1: Improved student learning: 100% of the students in Bioinformatics Concentration are required to work on hands-on, real-life bioinformatics problems by utilizing the resources of the Bioinformatics Laboratory.

Outcome-1.2: Integration of research into education: 100% of the students in Bioinformatics Concentration are required to develop a Senior Project (two-semester long) in a bioinformatics research area.

Outcome-1.3: Improving faculty research: The Computer Science and Biological Sciences faculty have already received additional funding from NIH and NSF with support of this project.

OBJECTIVE-2: Enhance the joint Bioinformatics Concentration of the Departments of Computer Science and Biological Sciences.

Outcome-2.1: Boosting interest in Bioinformatics: Eight (8) computer science students have graduated under bioinformatics concentration so far and there are currently about ten (10) students in this concentration.

Outcome-2.2: Improving readiness of students for graduate study:  About 30% of the Bioinformatics Concentration students pursue graduate studies.

OBJECTIVE-3: Prepare a globally competitive workforce in Bioinformatics.

Outcome-3.1: Readiness for graduate studies or industry: 100% of the Bioinformatics Concentration Students complete  class projects in two (2) undergraduate bioinformatics courses as well as a year-long senior project.

Modified by: Ali S Sekmen
